an8.8:1.1: At one time Venerable Uttara was staying on the Saṅkheyyaka Mountain in the Mahisa region near Dhavajālikā.
an8.8:1.3: “Mendicants, it’s good for a mendicant to check their own failings from time to time.
an8.8:1.4: It’s good for a mendicant to check the failings of others from time to time.
an8.8:1.5: It’s good for a mendicant to check their own successes from time to time.
an8.8:1.6: It’s good for a mendicant to check the successes of others from time to time.”
an8.8:2.1: Now at that time the great king Vessavaṇa was on his way from the north to the south on some business.
an8.8:2.2: He heard Venerable Uttara teaching this to the mendicants on Saṅkheyyaka Mountain.
an8.8:3.1: Then Vessavaṇa vanished from Saṅkheyyaka Mountain and appeared among the gods of the Thirty-Three, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm.
an8.8:3.2: Then he went up to Sakka, lord of gods, and said to him:
an8.8:3.4: Venerable Uttara is teaching the mendicants on Saṅkheyyaka Mountain in this way:
an8.8:3.5: ‘It’s good for a mendicant from time to time to check their own failings. …
an8.8:4.1: Then, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, Sakka vanished from the gods of the Thirty-Three and reappeared on Saṅkheyyaka Mountain in front of Venerable Uttara.
an8.8:4.2: Then Sakka went up to Venerable Uttara, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him:
an8.8:5.1: “Is it really true, sir, that you teach the mendicants in this way:
an8.8:5.2: ‘It’s good for a mendicant from time to time to check their own failings …
an8.8:5.7: “Sir, did this teaching come to you from your own inspiration, or was it spoken by the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha?”
an8.8:5.8: “Well then, lord of gods, I shall give you a simile.
an8.8:5.9: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.
an8.8:6.1: Suppose there was a large heap of grain not far from a town or village.
an8.8:6.2: And a large crowd were to take away grain
an8.8:6.3: with carrying poles, baskets, hip sacks, or their cupped hands.
an8.8:6.4: If someone were to go to that crowd and ask them
an8.8:6.5: where they got the grain from, how should that crowd rightly reply?”
an8.8:6.6: “Sir, they should reply that they took it from the large heap of grain.”
an8.8:6.7: “In the same way, lord of gods, whatever is well spoken is spoken by the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
an8.8:6.8: Both myself and others rely completely on that when we speak.”
an8.8:7.2: How well this was said by Venerable Uttara!
an8.8:7.3: ‘Whatever is well spoken is spoken by the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
an8.8:7.4: Both myself and others rely completely on that when we speak.’
an8.8:7.5: At one time, Honorable Uttara, the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain, not long after Devadatta had left.
an8.8:7.6: There the Buddha spoke to the mendicants about Devadatta:
an8.8:8.1: ‘Mendicants, it’s good for a mendicant from time to time to check their own failings …
an8.8:8.5: Overcome and overwhelmed by eight things that oppose the true teaching, Devadatta is going to a place of loss, to hell, there to remain for an eon, irredeemable.
an8.8:8.14: bad friendship, Devadatta is going to a place of loss, to hell, there to remain for an eon, irredeemable.
an8.8:8.15: Overcome and overwhelmed by these eight things that oppose the true teaching, Devadatta is going to a place of loss, to hell, there to remain for an eon, irredeemable.
an8.8:9.1: It’s good for a mendicant, whenever they encounter it, to overcome gain …
an8.8:10.1: What advantage does a mendicant gain by overcoming these eight things?
an8.8:11.1: The distressing and feverish defilements that might arise in someone who lives without overcoming these eight things do not arise when they have overcome them.
an8.8:11.9: This is the advantage that a mendicant gains by overcoming these eight things.
an8.8:12.1: So you should train like this:
an8.8:12.2: “Whenever we encounter it, we will overcome gain …
an8.8:13.1: Honorable Uttara, this exposition of the teaching is not established anywhere in the four assemblies—
an8.8:13.4: Sir, learn this exposition of the teaching!
an8.8:13.5: Memorize this exposition of the teaching!
an8.8:13.6: Remember this exposition of the teaching!
an8.8:13.7: Sir, this exposition of the teaching is beneficial and relates to the fundamentals of the spiritual life.”
